item.title: LSAT Scores and Bar Exam are Compared at Law Schools
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Applicants' performance on the LSAT is often an indicator of how well they'll do on the bar exam.

At law Schools, the LSAT and the bar exam are two important barriers to cross for aspiring lawyers. Almost students believe test-takers' performance on the former is a certainly indicator of how they'll do on the latter, which could beso this can be the bad news for law applicants with low LSAT scores.

Erica Moeser, president and CEO of the National Conference of Bar Examiners says "If you get a low LSAT score, you maybe also have a low MBE score when you emerge from law school and take the bar exam,". And the MBE, or Multistate Bar Examination, is one part of the bar exam in most states.

However Students with high LSAT scores, aren't guaranteed to pass the bar at the first time around. And some law schools appear to do a better job than others at preparing their students for the bar exam.

At Yale University, the No. 1 ranked law school in the 2017 Best Law Schools, the average of LSAT score for all program entrants in 2015 was 173 — not far from the test's highest score of 180. The pass rate for Yale graduates who took the New York bar exam for the first time in 2014 was 96.4 percent .

While at Stanford University, which tied for No. 2 in the rankings, entering students had LSAT scores that were almost as high, but the pass rate for graduates taking the California bar was only 86.8 percent in 2014. However, Stanford grads actually beat their state's overall bar passage rate by nearly 45 percent, while Yale grads beat the New York pass rate by only 32.1 percent.

Some states' bar exams are considered to be more difficult than others. Such as California's overall bar passage rate for first time test around  in 2014 was just 60 percent, compared with New York's 73 percent.

School (name; state) Median LSAT score for 2015 competitors 2014 bar passage rate for first time test round (state) Bar passage rate in that state How much better grads did than state bar passage rate U.S. News rank
Harvard University (MA) 173 97.3% (NY) 73% 33.3% 2 (tie)
Yale University (CT) 173 96.4% (NY) 73% 32.1% 1
Columbia University (NY) 171 92.4% (NY) 73% 26.6% 4 (tie)
Stanford University (CA) 171 86.8% (CA) 60% 44.7% 2 (tie)
University of Chicago 170 97.3% (IL) 85% 14.5% 4 (tie)
Duke University (NC) 169 94.3% (NY) 73% 29.2% 11
New York University 169 95.7% (NY) 73% 31.1% 6
University of Pennsylvania 169 99.3% (NY) 73% 36% 7
Northwestern University (Pritzker) (IL) 168 92.4% (IL) 85% 8.7% 12
University of Michigan—Ann Arbor 168 92.9% (NY) 73% 27.3% 8 (tie)
University of Virginia 168 98% (NY) 73% 34.2% 8 (tie)

The largest number of graduates on the list took the bar exam in New York, California or Illinois in 2014.

At many schools, LSAT scores for incoming students have declined in recent years.

For example, at Georgetown University, the bottom 25 percent of applicants who were accepted had a score of 168 or lower in 2010. By 2013, the bottom 25 percent scored 163 or lower,according to the National Conference of Bar Examiners.

But according to the Law School Admission Council, the average among all U.S. schools approved by the American Bar Association has remained stable. In every testing year from 2007-2008 to 2013-2014, the LSATscore  indicated between 150 and 151.

However, data from the National Conference of Bar Examiners show the average pass rate for first time test around of the bar exam across the country declined from 79 percent in 2007 to just 74 percent in 2014 during that same time period.

Moeser from the National Conference of Bar Examiners says the prospective students should know the LSAT isn't the only indicator of success on the bar exam. "Students who have high law school grade-point averages are more likely to do well on the bar exam than those who have low law school grade-point averages,"

Experts say that passing the bar exam is the last step to becoming a practicing lawyer, it doesn't necessarily ensure a successful career.

Allen Mendenhall, an assistant attorney general for the state of Alabama, wrote that "LSAT and bar performance are not always reliable indicators of legal skill and competence of students at school,". But Mendenhall  also emphasized that his views are his alone and not a reflection of the Alabama attorney general's, has long criticized the bar exam. He encourages law applicants to take both exams seriously. He wrote: “To me, the bar exam, which the disciplined lawyers had all passed, was not always successful in removing bad lawyers from good lawyers. However, here's no formula for success on the LSAT or bar exam. In my view, A strict, regimented study schedule remains the best mode of preparation."
item.category: LSAT Scores and Bar Exam are Compared at Law Schools
